title: CS104 Midterm Exam
instructions: This exam covers Topics 1-4: Arrays/Linked Lists, Stacks/Queues, Trees, and Hash Tables.
Answer all questions. Passing score is 70% or higher.
For code output questions, provide exact output including formatting.
For fill-in-blank questions, use lowercase answers.
Show your work for partial credit on written questions.

questions.prompt: What is the time complexity of accessing an element by index in an array?
questions.explanation: Arrays provide O(1) random access because elements are stored contiguously, allowing direct address calculation.

questions.prompt: Which operation is MORE efficient in a singly linked list compared to an array?
questions.explanation: Inserting at the beginning of a linked list is O(1) (just update head pointer), while arrays require O(n) shifting.

questions.prompt: What does this code print?
questions.codeSnippet:
class Node:
    def __init__(self, val):
        self.val = val
        self.next = None

head = Node(1)
head.next = Node(2)
head.next.next = Node(3)
curr = head
while curr:
    print(curr.val, end='->')
    curr = curr.next
print('None')
questions.explanation: The traversal visits each node (1, 2, 3) printing value followed by ->, then prints None at the end.

questions.prompt: To reverse a singly linked list in-place, you need O(n) extra space.
questions.explanation: Reversing a linked list in-place requires only O(1) extra space (3 pointers: prev, curr, next).

questions.prompt: The two-pointer technique using slow and fast pointers is also called the ____ and ____ algorithm.
questions.explanation: Floyd's cycle detection algorithm uses two pointers moving at different speeds, nicknamed tortoise (slow) and hare (fast).

questions.prompt: Explain why arrays have better cache performance than linked lists. What is spatial locality and how does it apply here?
questions.explanation: Arrays have better cache performance because they store elements in contiguous memory locations. Spatial locality is the principle that when one memory location is accessed, nearby locations are likely to be accessed soon. CPUs take advantage of this by loading blocks of nearby memory into the cache. Since array elements are contiguous, accessing one element brings nearby elements into cache. In contrast, linked list nodes can be scattered throughout memory, so accessing one node doesn't help with accessing the next node, resulting in more cache misses.
questions.modelAnswer: Arrays have better cache performance because they store elements in contiguous memory locations. Spatial locality is the principle that when one memory location is accessed, nearby locations are likely to be accessed soon. CPUs take advantage of this by loading blocks of nearby memory into the cache. Since array elements are contiguous, accessing one element brings nearby elements into cache. In contrast, linked list nodes can be scattered throughout memory, so accessing one node doesn't help with accessing the next node, resulting in more cache misses.

questions.prompt: Write a function that finds the middle node of a linked list. If there are two middle nodes, return the second one. Explain your approach.
questions.explanation:
def find_middle(head):
    slow = fast = head
    while fast and fast.next:
        slow = slow.next
        fast = fast.next.next
    return slow

Use the two-pointer technique: slow pointer moves one step at a time while fast pointer moves two steps. When fast reaches the end, slow will be at the middle. For even-length lists, this returns the second middle node as required.
questions.modelAnswer:
def find_middle(head):
    slow = fast = head
    while fast and fast.next:
        slow = slow.next
        fast = fast.next.next
    return slow

Use the two-pointer technique: slow pointer moves one step at a time while fast pointer moves two steps. When fast reaches the end, slow will be at the middle. For even-length lists, this returns the second middle node as required.

questions.prompt: Which data structure follows LIFO (Last-In-First-Out) ordering?
questions.explanation: Stacks follow LIFO: the most recently added element is removed first.

questions.prompt: What is printed after these operations?
questions.codeSnippet:
stack = []
stack.append(10)
stack.append(20)
stack.append(30)
print(stack.pop())
stack.append(40)
print(stack.pop())
print(stack[-1])

questions.prompt: In Python, using list.pop(0) for queue operations is O(1).
questions.explanation: list.pop(0) is O(n) because all elements must shift. Use collections.deque for O(1) popleft().

questions.prompt: Which application is a classic use case for stacks?
questions.explanation: Stacks are perfect for matching brackets: push opening brackets, pop when closing brackets match.

questions.prompt: Evaluate this postfix expression: 3 4 + 2 * 7 -
questions.explanation: 3+4=7, 7*2=14, 14-7=7. Operations: push 3,4 -> pop,add,push 7 -> push 2 -> pop,mul,push 14 -> push 7 -> pop,sub,push 7.

questions.prompt: Write a function to check if a string of parentheses is valid. A string is valid if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket in the correct order. Explain your approach.
In a Binary Search Tree, all values in the left subtree of a node are:
questions.explanation: BST property: left subtree values < node value < right subtree values.

questions.prompt: ____ traversal of a BST visits nodes in sorted (ascending) order.
questions.explanation: Inorder traversal (left-root-right) visits BST nodes in ascending sorted order.

questions.prompt:
What is the preorder traversal of this BST?
      5
     / \
    3   7
   /     \
  1       9
questions.explanation: Preorder visits: 5 (root) -> 3 (left) -> 1 (left of 3) -> 7 (right of 5) -> 9 (right of 7).

questions.prompt: The worst-case time complexity for searching in a BST is O(log n).
questions.explanation: Worst case is O(n) when the BST is skewed (degenerates to a linked list). O(log n) is for balanced BSTs.

questions.prompt: Which traversal uses a queue to process nodes level by level?
questions.explanation: Level-order traversal uses a queue to process all nodes at each level before moving to the next.

questions.prompt: Explain the difference between a binary tree and a binary search tree. Why is the BST property important for search operations?
questions.explanation: A binary tree is a tree where each node has at most 2 children. A binary search tree (BST) is a special binary tree with the property that for every node, all values in the left subtree are less than the node value, and all values in the right subtree are greater. This BST property enables binary search: at each node, we can eliminate half the tree by comparing the target with the current node and choosing left or right. This gives O(log n) search time in balanced BSTs, compared to O(n) for regular binary trees where we might need to check every node.
questions.modelAnswer: A binary tree is a tree where each node has at most 2 children. A binary search tree (BST) is a special binary tree with the property that for every node, all values in the left subtree are less than the node value, and all values in the right subtree are greater. This BST property enables binary search: at each node, we can eliminate half the tree by comparing the target with the current node and choosing left or right. This gives O(log n) search time in balanced BSTs, compared to O(n) for regular binary trees where we might need to check every node.

questions.prompt: Write a function to find the maximum depth (height) of a binary tree. Explain your approach.
What is the average-case time complexity for hash table lookup?
questions.explanation: Hash tables provide O(1) average lookup by computing array index directly from the key.

questions.prompt: When two different keys produce the same hash value, this is called a ____.
questions.explanation: A collision occurs when hash(key1) == hash(key2) for key1 != key2.

questions.prompt: Which collision resolution strategy stores multiple key-value pairs at the same bucket using a linked list?
questions.explanation: Chaining resolves collisions by maintaining a linked list (or other structure) at each bucket.

questions.prompt: What does this code print?
questions.explanation: d["a"] is overwritten to 10. d.get("x", 0) returns default 0 since "x" doesn't exist.

questions.prompt: In Python, mutable objects like lists can be used as dictionary keys.
questions.explanation: Dictionary keys must be hashable. Lists are mutable and not hashable, so cannot be keys.

questions.prompt: Write a function that returns the first non-repeating character in a string, or None if all characters repeat. Explain your approach.

title: CS104 Final Exam
instructions: This comprehensive exam covers all 7 topics.
Answer all questions. Passing score is 70% or higher.
For code output questions, provide exact output.
For fill-in-blank questions, use lowercase answers.
Time management: approximately 3 minutes per question.

questions.prompt: What is the time complexity of inserting an element at the beginning of an array?
questions.explanation: Inserting at the beginning requires shifting all n elements, making it O(n).

questions.prompt: What is printed?
questions.explanation: arr[-2:] = [4, 5], arr[:-2] = [1, 2, 3]. Concatenation gives right rotation by 2.

questions.prompt: A doubly linked list requires more memory per node than a singly linked list.
questions.explanation: Doubly linked lists store two pointers (next and prev) vs one (next) in singly linked lists.

questions.prompt: Floyd's cycle detection algorithm uses:
questions.explanation: Floyd's algorithm uses two pointers (O(1) space) and traverses the list once (O(n) time).

questions.prompt: An LRU Cache is typically implemented using a hash map and a ____ linked list.
questions.explanation: Doubly linked list allows O(1) removal from any position, needed for LRU eviction.

questions.prompt: Write a function to reverse a linked list in-place. Explain your approach.
questions.explanation:
def reverse_list(head):
    prev = None
    curr = head
    while curr:
        next_node = curr.next
        curr.next = prev
        prev = curr
        curr = next_node
    return prev

Maintain three pointers: prev (initially None), curr (starts at head), and next_node. For each node, save the next node, reverse the link to point to prev, then advance prev and curr. When curr becomes None, prev will be the new head.
questions.modelAnswer:
def reverse_list(head):
    prev = None
    curr = head
    while curr:
        next_node = curr.next
        curr.next = prev
        prev = curr
        curr = next_node
    return prev

Maintain three pointers: prev (initially None), curr (starts at head), and next_node. For each node, save the next node, reverse the link to point to prev, then advance prev and curr. When curr becomes None, prev will be the new head.

questions.prompt: Which algorithm uses a queue for traversal?
questions.explanation: BFS uses a queue to explore vertices level by level. DFS uses a stack.

questions.prompt: What is printed?
questions.codeSnippet:
from collections import deque
q = deque([1, 2, 3])
q.append(4)
print(q.popleft())
q.appendleft(0)
print(list(q))
questions.explanation: Initial: [1,2,3]. append(4): [1,2,3,4]. popleft(): returns 1, leaves [2,3,4]. appendleft(0): [0,2,3,4].

questions.prompt: A monotonic stack can solve "next greater element" problems in O(n) time.
questions.explanation: Monotonic stack processes each element at most twice (push and pop), giving O(n) overall.

questions.prompt: A deque (double-ended queue) supports:
options: Operations at both ends in O(1)
questions.explanation: Deque provides O(1) insertion and deletion at both front and back.

questions.prompt: Explain how you would implement a queue using two stacks. Describe the time complexity of enqueue and dequeue operations.
questions.explanation: Use two stacks: stack1 for enqueue and stack2 for dequeue. For enqueue, simply push to stack1 (O(1)). For dequeue, if stack2 is empty, transfer all elements from stack1 to stack2 (reversing their order), then pop from stack2. While a single dequeue might take O(n) when transferring, each element is moved at most once from stack1 to stack2, giving amortized O(1) time for dequeue operations.
questions.modelAnswer: Use two stacks: stack1 for enqueue and stack2 for dequeue. For enqueue, simply push to stack1 (O(1)). For dequeue, if stack2 is empty, transfer all elements from stack1 to stack2 (reversing their order), then pop from stack2. While a single dequeue might take O(n) when transferring, each element is moved at most once from stack1 to stack2, giving amortized O(1) time for dequeue operations.

questions.prompt: Implement a MinStack that supports push, pop, top, and getMin in O(1) time. Explain your approach.
Which self-balancing BST uses rotations to maintain balance?
questions.explanation: AVL trees maintain balance (heights differ by at most 1) using rotations after insertions/deletions.

questions.prompt:
What is the inorder traversal of this BST?
      8
     / \
    4  12
   /    \
  2     14
questions.explanation: Inorder of BST gives sorted order: 2 -> 4 -> 8 -> 12 -> 14.

questions.prompt: The Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) of two nodes is the ____ node that has both as descendants.
questions.explanation: LCA is the deepest (closest to leaves) ancestor that contains both nodes in its subtree.

questions.prompt: Level-order traversal of a binary tree requires O(n) extra space in the worst case.
questions.explanation: In the worst case (complete tree), the last level has n/2 nodes, all in the queue simultaneously.

questions.prompt: To validate a BST, what must you check for each node?
options: Entire left subtree < node < entire right subtree
questions.explanation: BST validation requires ALL left subtree values < node AND ALL right subtree values > node.

questions.prompt: Write a function to check if a binary tree is a valid BST. Explain your approach.
What causes hash table operations to degrade to O(n)?
options: All keys hash to the same bucket
questions.explanation: When all keys collide to one bucket, operations must search through all n elements.

questions.prompt: What is printed?
questions.codeSnippet:
from collections import Counter
s = "aabbbcc"
c = Counter(s)
print(c.most_common(2))
questions.explanation: Counter counts: a:2, b:3, c:2. most_common(2) returns the top 2 by count. When counts are tied (a and c both have 2), insertion order is preserved, so 'a' comes before 'c'. Result: [('b', 3), ('a', 2)].

questions.prompt: The ratio of elements to buckets in a hash table is called the ____ factor.
questions.explanation: Load factor = n / capacity. High load factor increases collisions; typically resize at 0.75.

questions.prompt: Python sets use hash tables internally.
questions.explanation: Python sets are implemented as hash tables with only keys (no values), providing O(1) membership testing.

questions.prompt: To solve "Two Sum" in O(n) time, you should use:
questions.explanation: Hash table stores each number's index; for each number, check if (target - number) exists in O(1).

questions.prompt: Write a function to group anagrams from a list of strings. Explain your approach.
What is the space complexity of an adjacency list for a graph with V vertices and E edges?
questions.explanation: Adjacency list stores V lists plus E total edges across all lists: O(V + E).

questions.prompt: A directed graph with no cycles is called a ____ (abbreviation).
questions.explanation: DAG stands for Directed Acyclic Graph.

questions.prompt: BFS finds the shortest path in weighted graphs.
questions.explanation: BFS finds shortest paths only in unweighted graphs. Use Dijkstra's for weighted graphs.

questions.prompt: Topological sort is only possible for:
questions.explanation: Topological ordering requires a DAG; cycles make linear ordering impossible.

questions.prompt:
How many connected components does this graph have?
Vertices: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
Edges: (0,1), (1,2), (3,4)
questions.explanation: Three components: {0,1,2} connected, {3,4} connected, and {5} isolated.

questions.prompt: Write a function to detect if a directed graph has a cycle using DFS. Explain your approach.
Which sorting algorithm has O(n log n) time complexity in ALL cases?
questions.explanation: Merge sort is always O(n log n). Quick sort can degrade to O(n²) with poor pivot selection.

questions.prompt: Insertion sort is efficient for nearly sorted arrays.
questions.explanation: Insertion sort is O(n) for nearly sorted data because elements need minimal movement.

questions.prompt: A sorting algorithm is ____ if equal elements maintain their original relative order.
questions.explanation: Stable sorts preserve the input order of equal elements (e.g., merge sort, insertion sort).

questions.prompt: After one pass of bubble sort on [5, 1, 4, 2, 8], what is the array?
questions.codeSnippet: # Bubble largest to end in one pass

questions.prompt: Quick sort's worst case O(n²) occurs when:
options: Pivot is always min or max
questions.explanation: Poor pivot selection (always min/max) creates maximally unbalanced partitions.

questions.prompt: Write a function to merge two sorted arrays into one sorted array. Explain your approach.
questions.modelAnswer:
def merge(arr1, arr2):
    result = []
    i = j = 0
    while i < len(arr1) and j < len(arr2):
        if arr1[i] <= arr2[j]:
            result.append(arr1[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            result.append(arr2[j])
            j += 1
    result.extend(arr1[i:])
    result.extend(arr2[j:])
    return result

Use two pointers, one for each array. Compare elements and append the smaller one to the result. When one array is exhausted, append the remaining elements from the other array. This is O(n+m) time, the core operation in merge sort.
questions.explanation:
def merge(arr1, arr2):
    result = []
    i = j = 0
    while i < len(arr1) and j < len(arr2):
        if arr1[i] <= arr2[j]:
            result.append(arr1[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            result.append(arr2[j])
            j += 1
    result.extend(arr1[i:])
    result.extend(arr2[j:])
    return result

Use two pointers, one for each array. Compare elements and append the smaller one to the result. When one array is exhausted, append the remaining elements from the other array. This is O(n+m) time, the core operation in merge sort.

questions.prompt: In a min-heap, the parent is always:
options: Less than or equal to children
Less than left, greater than right
questions.explanation: Min-heap property: parent <= children. Root is always the minimum element.

questions.prompt: What is printed?
questions.codeSnippet:
import heapq
h = [5, 3, 8, 1]
heapq.heapify(h)
print(heapq.heappop(h))
print(heapq.heappop(h))
questions.explanation: heapify creates min-heap [1,3,8,5]. First pop returns 1, second pop returns 3.

questions.prompt: For a node at index i in a 0-indexed heap array, its parent is at index ____ (formula using floor division).
questions.explanation: Parent index = (i-1)//2. Left child = 2i+1, Right child = 2i+2.

questions.prompt: Building a heap from n elements takes O(n) time, not O(n log n).
questions.explanation: Bottom-up heapify takes O(n). Only inserting n elements one by one takes O(n log n).

questions.prompt: To find the k largest elements from n elements efficiently, use:
questions.explanation: Min-heap of size k: keep k largest by removing smallest when heap exceeds k. O(n log k).

questions.prompt: Write a function to find the kth largest element in an array using a heap. Explain your approach.
